title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: very considerable accommodation.* At the west end are the Barracks, a shooting-lodge (the property of Robertson of Struan), and Rannoch Lodge (Sir Robert Menzies, Bart.) ; and here the loch receives the superfluous waters of Loch Lydoch on the west, and Loch Ericht on the north.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The north side is possessed by Sir Robert Menzies, the south by Robertson of Struan, and the eastern extremity by General Macdonald.

title: Letters from Thomas Percy, D.D. :
snippet: Robertson of Struan, who had been in the rebellions of J 715 and 1745, and who (he says) left behind him a volume of elegies and other pieces.* I should be glad if you could inform me when and where they were printed, and what degree of merit they have : if worth buying, I should be glad if you would procure me the volume ; the price of which I shall, with thanks, repay you : being, with great regard, &c.

title: John Splendid;
author: Munro, Neil
snippet: On a plain called Leiter- nan-lub the battalion lay camped, a mere fragment  of the force that brought ruin to Argile's Athole men under the Tutor of Struan, Stewarts of Appin, Maclans of Glencoe, a few of the more sedate men of Glengarry, Keppoch, and Maclean, as well ^ as a handful of the Gregaraich who had captured us.

title: Tales and sketches.
author: Miller, Hugh
snippet: He was named Robertson ; and as there were several  of the Robertsons of Struan among the party, he was soon on very excellent terras with them.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: For one thing Struan was remarkable, even among good shots: he was the most humane sportsman we ever saw; he never shot but he hit, and he never hit but he killed.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: We remember  well his sudden appearance at the great fire in Leilh Street some six-and-twenty years ago, — as a stripling in Highland ball-dress, — with a company of his men whom he had led from the Castle; how he took, as if by right, the command of every one, and worked like Tela- monian Ajax (who we are sure was like him) at the engines; how the boys gloried in him, saying, "There's young Struan; he works Hke six!" and so he did.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: Struan was in the Forty-Second when young.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: Though he was but occasionally in Edinburgh, Struan was better known than many men who never leave it; and all felt proud of watching the manly, athletic, and agile chief, with his stern and powerful look as of an eagle, —

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: hardy ; and any one seeing him with ladies or children or old people would agree with one half of King Jamie's Baying, " A' the 'sons " (men with names ending in son like Wilson, Nicholson, etc.) " are carles' sons, but Struan Robertson 's a gentleman's."

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: For one thing Struan was remarkable, even among good shots ; he was the most humane sportsman we ever saw ; he never shot but he hit, and he never hit but he killed.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: We remember well his sudden appearance at the great fire in Leith Street some six-and-twenty years ago, — as a stripling in Highland ball-dress, — with a company of his men whom he had led from the Castle ; how he took, as if by right, the command  of every one, and worked like Telamonian Ajax (who we are sure was like him) at the engines ; how the boys gloried in him, saying, " There 's young Struan ; he works like six ! " and so he did.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Struan was in the Forty-Second when young.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Though he was but occasionally in Edinburgh, Struan was better known than many men who never leave it ;

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Struan Robertson — or, as he was best known, Struan^ not the Struan, the head of the clan Donachie, and representative of one of the oldest families in the North, who were Counts of Athole before the Murrays, and once owned land from the watershed of the Moor of Rannoch to within a mile of Perth, and were always " out " when anybody was, — was laid in his grave on Monday last, carried shoulder-high by his men and the stout shepherds of Rannoch, and lowered into his rest by his brother-officers of the Athole Guard.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Struan Robertson — or, as he was best known, Struan^ not the Struan, the head of the clan Donachie, and representative of one of the oldest families in the North, who were Counts of Athole before the Murrays, and once owned land from the watershed of the Moor of Rannoch to within a mile of Perth, and were always " out " when anybody was, — was laid in his grave on Monday last, carried shoulder-high by his men and the stout shepherds of Rannoch, and lowered into his rest by his brother-officers of the Athole Guard.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Struan Robertson — or, as he was best known, Struan^ not the Struan, the head of the clan Donachie, and representative of one of the oldest families in the North, who were Counts of Athole before the Murrays, and once owned land from the watershed of the Moor of Rannoch to within a mile of Perth, and were always " out " when anybody was, — was laid in his grave on Monday last, carried shoulder-high by his men and the stout shepherds of Rannoch, and lowered into his rest by his brother-officers of the Athole Guard.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: His Athole guard (many of whom, with Struan at their head, were his peers in birth) would have died for him, not in word, but in deed ; and a young, capable shepherd, who might have pushed his fortune anywhere and to any length, was more than rewarded for living a solitary deer-keeper at the far-end of Glen Tilt, or up some to us nameless wild, where for months he saw no living thing but his dog and the deer, the eagles and the hill fox, the raven and the curlew, — by his £18 a year, his £3 for milk, his six bolls and a half of oatmeal, with his annual coat of gray tweed, his kilt and his hose, — so that he had the chance of a kind word or nod from the Duke, or, more blessed still, a friendly pipe with him in his hut, with a confidential  chat on the interests of the " Forest."

title: Journal of a Summer Tour in the Perthshire and Inverness-shire Highlands
author: Roger, James Cruikshank.
snippet: He imagined that Dundee and hismen were lying at Struan, 4 miles north of this,for a considerable time before the battle.
